snippet.textDisplay: Little bit of oversharing for a youtube comment, but due to an issue with repressed memories and being drugged by an abusive parent until i was 13ish, I realized that despite remembering this as one of the most enjoyable games I ever played, I have almost zero memory of it after the first hour (along with most things from my life before high school), no matter how hard I try to remember. I'm not looking for pity, I'm long past all of that, being 20 surrounded by great friends and in an amazing several year long relationship with someone I really want to marry. The way I see it, I have a privilege that many before me and i'm sure some reading this comment wish they could have, I get to play Chrono Trigger for the first time again. And I can not wait.
snippet.textOriginal: Little bit of oversharing for a youtube comment, but due to an issue with repressed memories and being drugged by an abusive parent until i was 13ish, I realized that despite remembering this as one of the most enjoyable games I ever played, I have almost zero memory of it after the first hour (along with most things from my life before high school), no matter how hard I try to remember. I'm not looking for pity, I'm long past all of that, being 20 surrounded by great friends and in an amazing several year long relationship with someone I really want to marry. The way I see it, I have a privilege that many before me and i'm sure some reading this comment wish they could have, I get to play Chrono Trigger for the first time again. And I can not wait.

snippet.textDisplay: Usually games/movies with time travel focus on the future being more interesting and how events today influence that future outcome. This game reverses that and makes it so the past is the most interesting and mysterious part of the world, and the things that happen in that time period shape the present reality. This game and especially the music from 12,000 BC era captures the mystique perfectly. It feels like the height of advancement, and in many ways it is--the Gurus shape the world by employing their understanding in concrete ways, but are influenced and forced to work under a selfish and vain leader, oddly freed from her by Lavos own action to split them up in time. Even though all 3 are separated, they still use their knowledge and abilities to do things that together, unbeknownst to them all, work together to save the world, without them being certain of the outcome. Courage and hope displayed in spite of the overwhelming calamity they witnessed at the hands of Lavos. While I don't know if this is a reference to the trinity of God, I do find it interesting that all 3 of them seem to be of one mind and action in many ways, made manifest in different forms, and that their assistance to the heroes is selfless. Also interesting is that the seemingly victorious action of the enemy itself leads paradoxically to it's defeat. (Lavos freeing the gurus from the influence and command of Queen Zeal by throwing them into different parts of time)
snippet.textOriginal: Usually games/movies with time travel focus on the future being more interesting and how events today influence that future outcome. This game reverses that and makes it so the past is the most interesting and mysterious part of the world, and the things that happen in that time period shape the present reality. This game and especially the music from 12,000 BC era captures the mystique perfectly. It feels like the height of advancement, and in many ways it is--the Gurus shape the world by employing their understanding in concrete ways, but are influenced and forced to work under a selfish and vain leader, oddly freed from her by Lavos own action to split them up in time. Even though all 3 are separated, they still use their knowledge and abilities to do things that together, unbeknownst to them all, work together to save the world, without them being certain of the outcome. Courage and hope displayed in spite of the overwhelming calamity they witnessed at the hands of Lavos. While I don't know if this is a reference to the trinity of God, I do find it interesting that all 3 of them seem to be of one mind and action in many ways, made manifest in different forms, and that their assistance to the heroes is selfless. Also interesting is that the seemingly victorious action of the enemy itself leads paradoxically to it's defeat. (Lavos freeing the gurus from the influence and command of Queen Zeal by throwing them into different parts of time)

snippet.textDisplay:
...This tune gives me some serious Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind vibes, to the point where I have to wonder why I never noticed before.

The intro sounds like kind of a mix of multiple BG tracks connected to the Sea of Corruption. After that, the tune basically sounds like the melody 1 minute into the  track "The Princess Who Loves Insects".

I do know for a fact that Square took some inspiration from Nausicaä back in the 8-bit days, such as the chocobo basically being a horse-claw, but I never thought there might be musical inspiration as well, a good eleven years later.
snippet.textOriginal:
...This tune gives me some serious Nausicaä of the Valley of the Wind vibes, to the point where I have to wonder why I never noticed before.

The intro sounds like kind of a mix of multiple BG tracks connected to the Sea of Corruption. After that, the tune basically sounds like the melody 1 minute into the  track "The Princess Who Loves Insects".

I do know for a fact that Square took some inspiration from Nausicaä back in the 8-bit days, such as the chocobo basically being a horse-claw, but I never thought there might be musical inspiration as well, a good eleven years later.

snippet.textDisplay:
Even after all these tears, I still can't find any words fitting enough to describe how much I love Chrono Trigger
I happened to play it for the first time around 2010, I was like 11 at the time
And from the first second of the game I knew that I would never find a better or even matching game (that was before I discovered FFVI, which I equally rank with CT as my favorite game ever)

How can such a wonderful thing exist? I feel so blessed that I had the chance to finish it, it feels like a heaven sent gift sometimes...

And there I come to Zeal... And stay on the world map for hours without touching my controller, just listening to that masterpiece we got here...
Even now when I listen to it again while closing my eyes I forget about all my life issues and let myself go away with the music

I unfortunetaly don't have as much time as I did when I was in middle school so I can't play it anymore bc my studies are way too much time-consuming but it will always have a special significance in my heart, even when I'm old I'll make sure thay my kids and grandkids get to play that game, whether they like it or not, at least I will have shared my passion for it

To this day, I have played a lot of games since I stumbled upon CT but no one was as good as it is, and whenever I have to talk about my videogames tastes I first mention Chrono Trigger

May Zeal live forever in our hearts!

snippet.textDisplay: Would love to hear this unplugged but all the real-instruments versions I've heard really downplay the bells or replace them with strings or piano. Would be really nice to hear it on something closer to the original sound - tubular bells or gamelan, maybe? The occasional strings sound a little like a sitar, which also never makes it into orchestral arrangements either.
snippet.textOriginal: Would love to hear this unplugged but all the real-instruments versions I've heard really downplay the bells or replace them with strings or piano. snippet.textDisplay: Sometimes I hope the Video game market crashes and only the purists would be left. The wrong people want a piece of the money the gaming industry is generating and that is influencing the creative direction of games negatively. Its really hard to get memorable experiences from AAA games today. Most memorable experiences come from small games like Hotline Miami etc.

snippet.textDisplay: Play it now and enjoy it. Speaking personally, I played Chrono Trigger when I was 10 or 11. It’s inseparable from my childhood. The wonder, the innocence, the possibilities that awaited the future, and the appreciation of the inevitable past has few connections greater than these sounds. It was a time I will hold dearly in the back of my mind.

The wonder, the innocence, the possibilities that awaited the future, and the appreciation of the inevitable past has few connections greater than these sounds. It was a time I will hold dearly in the back of my mind.

snippet.textDisplay: That era produced some of the best video game soundtracks of all time. In span of just 4 years, we had Final Fantasy VI, Chrono Trigger, Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, Final Fantasy VII, Zelda: Ocarina of Time, and Metal Gear Solid. I don't anticipate that level of quality over that short span of time being matched again.
snippet.textOriginal: That era produced some of the best video game soundtracks of all time. In span of just 4 years, we had Final Fantasy VI, Chrono Trigger, Castlevania: Symphony of the Night, Final Fantasy VII, Zelda: Ocarina of Time, and Metal Gear Solid. I don't anticipate that level of quality over that short span of time being matched again.

snippet.textDisplay: It’s a good vgm song. Hard to measure objectively what would make a vgm song “the best”. Chrono Trigger and Cross had some really catchy compositions that seemed to perfectly fit the technology used in producing them and themes communicated in those games. A shame most vgm these days seems a throwaway. Yasunori Mitsuda and many others of that era serve as examples of composing vgm with passion.
snippet.textOriginal: It’s a good vgm song. Hard to measure objectively what would make a vgm song “the best”. Chrono Trigger and Cross had some really catchy compositions that seemed to perfectly fit the technology used in producing them and themes communicated in those games. A shame most vgm these days seems a throwaway. Yasunori Mitsuda and many others of that era serve as examples of composing vgm with passion.

snippet.textDisplay: Its one of the top 3 or 5 tracks in the 16-bit audio processor era. I remember emulating this game 10 years later and getting to Zeal and it was a true set the controller down and stare slack jawed moment. Originally played on a crappy mono tv  speaker (the stereo effects are great) in a room full of 10 year olds, this was not able to be appreciated for what it was. This is a pure example of artists straining against limitations and creating something unique

snippet.textDisplay:
Woho, I just finished Chrono Trigger for the first time! Here is my personal opinions of the game. 

I have always loved the snes era so I thought I had missed out on something when I had not played Chrono Trigger. It turns out I got mixed feelings about the game though.

First of all did I not like the gameplay. I prefer regular turn based over this, like in earthbound or golden sun (man I love those two games). I am quite surprised over me not liking the gameplay since I usually like it when you mix things up in jrpgs (like in xenoblade or in earthbound where your life scrolls down instead of drops instantly after an attack), however in chrono trigger the gameplay was just stressful, which is the opposite of what I want from a jrpg!

And for the second, I did not like the fantasy setting the game was in. It just felt alot like dungeons and dragons or something similar. I am not a fan of fantasy overall, and I do not like dragon ball either so that does not make the setting any better. :(

These two complaints are probably the only reason why I have so many mixed feelings for the game. Unfortunately I did not like two very important aspects of the game. :( 

That being said, this is not a bad game! It is just not my game.. unfortunately.

However, I must say I found myself amazed over 12000 bc. That was so awesome! The snowstorm under the clouds, and then you ascend over the clouds and this music starts playing and you see that you are in a highly advanced city *shivers*. I think 12000 bc was the best part of the game, and probably the part of the game I found most memorable! Easily one of the most beautiful places in video game history!

snippet.textDisplay:
It's a little crazy, but if you're wearing headphones and you pay attention to the first instrument (the one that loops through the whole song), it sounds like it's spinning clockwise while making bell sounds on 3 (right), 6 (bottom), and 9 (left) and starting the loop again on 12 (top). Very fitting as it's like a clock and the song name is Corridors of TIME.

Maybe I'm overanalysing the song, but it makes me love it even more.

@***** Stop being such a smart ass. Everyone knows what stereo panning is, and let's not forget this game was made in 1995 for the SNES, probably didn't have the most pro sound engineering team and technical capabilities just to get a surround sound effect for one song for one game, when the intended clock effect can be achieved well enough with simple panning.
And the reason I personally didn't notice it was meant to sound like a clock was because I've never actually played this game before, and didn't know what it was about prior to coming across some videos and music, and I think it's fucking cool.

All you're doing is pointing out the obvious, and now you're being a condescending pretentious ass about it. Get the fuck out.

snippet.textDisplay:
​@Luis Gustavo Peçanha Oh wow, someone got salty. 
If you think I have nostalgia, tell me why I had more fun playing Final Fantasy Tactics and Vagrant Story recently (games I never played in the past) than playing most modern RPGs?
This literally ticks nostalgia off the possibilities. 
Besides, I'm not the only one saying. Play Resident Evil 6, and play Resident Evil 1, 2 and 3. 
Play Final Fantasy 13, and play Final Fantasy 6, 7, 8. 
You don't even have to play them, just check on Metacritic for the scores.
Regardless, I'm not an "old guy bla bla bla". I'm just someone with my own solid opinion, who is not brainwashed by modern gaming companies.

snippet.textDisplay: @Norm Conel No, most of the time it's because creating 3D graphics is a much bigger task to take on, hence the 2D/pixel art look. Some may be trying to go for that style on purpose like Shovel Knight but, most of these 2D indie games are just that, 2D because of the shear amount of extra work it takes to make a fully 3D game is exponentially higher & challenging. It's not a retro thing, they're just using there brains.
snippet.textOriginal: @Norm Conel No, most of the time it's because creating 3D graphics is a much bigger task to take on, hence the 2D/pixel art look. Some may be trying to go for that style on purpose like Shovel Knight but, most of these 2D indie games are just that, 2D because of the shear amount of extra work it takes to make a fully 3D game is exponentially higher & challenging. It's not a retro thing, they're just using there brains.

snippet.textDisplay: @Owari Dragon I completely agree, but I think that some indie developers use pixle/sprite graphics as an easy way to make a bland game popular BECAUSE of the success of games that use the aesthetic masterfully. I think some newer games could benefit from a original art style, or simply and art style that is used so much that it loses its impact. Thats why I feel a little guilty. But thats not to say that games like Shovel Knight shouldn't use a retro/nes era art style because, like you said, it's an homage to 8-bit games of a past time and benefits greatly from the use of the art style.
snippet.textOriginal: @Owari Dragon I completely agree, but I think that some indie developers use pixle/sprite graphics as an easy way to make a bland game popular BECAUSE of the success of games that use the aesthetic masterfully. I think some newer games could benefit from a original art style, or simply and art style that is used so much that it loses its impact. Thats why I feel a little guilty. But thats not to say that games like Shovel Knight shouldn't use a retro/nes era art style because, like you said, it's an homage to 8-bit games of a past time and benefits greatly from the use of the art style.

snippet.textDisplay: Zeal: the part of the game where I had no idea where I was and didn't have any idea of what to do. Like Alice tumbling down the rabbit hole all you could do was explore and let the plot unravel.
snippet.textOriginal: Zeal: the part of the game where I had no idea where I was and didn't have any idea of what to do. Like Alice tumbling down the rabbit hole all you could do was explore and let the plot unravel.

snippet.textDisplay: And that's exactly what the developers intended. After the red herring of Magus being the villain and the big build up to him and his giant dungeon, followed by the long Tyrano Lair, you wondered what would happen next. Well, I remember going through the portal and seeing an ice age world and I did not expect a new time period and then I ended up at Zeal. And the whole chapter is genius because the entire mission is based on exploration and eventually, it leads into the plot with the Ocean Palace.
snippet.textOriginal: And that's exactly what the developers intended. After the red herring of Magus being the villain and the big build up to him and his giant dungeon, followed by the long Tyrano Lair, you wondered what would happen next. Well, I remember going through the portal and seeing an ice age world and I did not expect a new time period and then I ended up at Zeal. And the whole chapter is genius because the entire mission is based on exploration and eventually, it leads into the plot with the Ocean Palace.

snippet.textDisplay:
If you add &hd=1 to the end of the url you get better sound, but video quality is the same. Pretty sure this works for a lot of videos listed as 240/360p, because years ago many videos that were 480p, and maybe 360p, became/were lowered to 240/360p. There may have also been videos that were originally 240p, but still had their audio quality lowered.

They seem to still be on YouTube's servers in their original quality, just not normally accessible without that extra bit of text at the end of the url. I found this out by trying it out one day a year or two ago, after realizing their were larger sizes available when I downloaded videos using KeepVid.

For example with this video what you normally see on Youtube is the one listed on KeepVid as 240p, and is 4.19MB in size. The one listed under "(Max 480p)" is 4.5MB in size. The video still appears to be of the same quality and 240p, but that extra 0.31MB seems to make a significant difference to the audio quality, allowing more depth of the music to come through. It's about a 6.9% difference in file size, and audio is usually significantly smaller than video, so this may be a large improvement one could expect in the sound on many videos.

My guess is that Youtube lowered the quality of many old videos years ago to save on bandwidth costs of people watching older videos that no longer provided them much profit, or something along those lines.

I realize &hd=1 is normally known for playing back videos at 720p, but it seems to work for setting videos to the highest quality they can be played at (other than 1080p or above) even if 720p is not available.

On this video I find listening to it without the &hd=1 added makes many of the sounds kind of dull/muffled/flat sounding. Hope this helps some people, enjoy.

snippet.textDisplay: Those 11 years were really something special, although 1987 was a great year for the company too. And although they haven't been at their best since the merge with Enix, 2006 was also a great year marked by the releases of Kingdom Hearts 2 and Final Fantasy XII, as well as the publication of Dragon Quest VIII in English. In truth the first 3 or 4 years after the merger weren't so bad, they still released a lot of great games in that time. But since 2007 only TWEWY and DQ IX have stood out.
snippet.textOriginal: Those 11 years were really something special, although 1987 was a great year for the company too. And although they haven't been at their best since the merge with Enix, 2006 was also a great year marked by the releases of Kingdom Hearts 2 and Final Fantasy XII, as well as the publication of Dragon Quest VIII in English. In truth the first 3 or 4 years after the merger weren't so bad, they still released a lot of great games in that time. But since 2007 only TWEWY and DQ IX have stood out.

snippet.textDisplay: Square Enix did still 'technically' make Chrono Trigger, because the merger hasn't changed anything really other than the company name. Everything Squaresoft developed is owned by Square Enix, and most of guys at the top are still there. A lot of the developers have left, so in essence the core of Squaresoft doesn't exist any more. But in reality they are still the same company, just merged. Just like Enix are still the same as before.

But in reality they are still the same company, just merged. Just like Enix are still the same as before.

snippet.textDisplay: Squaresoft really went downhill when they merged with Enix.  Chrono Trigger was my favorite video game of the entire 90s.  The music for the whole game, especially this track is so magical.  I would love to see a sequel with PS3 or PS4 graphics in the near future, but that will never happen.  I always got a kick when the Robo character said that the technology of Zeal in 10000 BC was better than 2300 AD when you are in the Dark Omen toward the end.
snippet.textOriginal: Squaresoft really went downhill when they merged with Enix.  Chrono Trigger was my favorite video game of the entire 90s.  The music for the whole game, especially this track is so magical.  I would love to see a sequel with PS3 or PS4 graphics in the near future, but that will never happen. snippet.textDisplay:
This BGM is living proof that there was a time where a game did not need high tech CGI to make your jaw drop to the floor.  The moment you end up in the Kingdom of Zeal is one of the most magical moments in gaming I have ever experienced.  

I played this game when i was 19 (one year ago) so no nostalgia involved here.

Chrono Trigger is one of the few RPGs where you will truly feel like your on an adventure, and will wow you at every turn.

snippet.textDisplay: Chrono Trigger is simply wonderful. The game play, the story, the characters, the atmosphere, the music. Everything comes together to create one of the most finely balanced video games you're ever likely to play. It's a real shame Square Enix don't make games as good as this any more. Truly one of the greatest achievements in the history of gaming.

Everything comes together to create one of the most finely balanced video games you're ever likely to play. It's a real shame Square Enix don't make games as good as this any more. Truly one of the greatest achievements in the history of gaming.

snippet.textDisplay: I have honestly given up on FF7. The game was good, very good. One of the main concerns about the game was it's plotholes, which the many many expansions kinds of patches over. I've seen the normal Advent Children, I haven't seen the Complete version - because frankly I just don't care. It was more fun back in 2000 when they let us make our own scenarios and find evidence for them all. They seem to be intent on removing the ability to put your own mark upon their world, if you get what I mean.

snippet.textDisplay:
Square's doing it right so far. 
Chrono Trigger on Playstation and Chrono Trigger DS weren't remakes at all, because the game itself was left virtually untouched. The only real noteworthy changes were that Frog's speech wasn't as "old English" on the DS, and they added awesome cutscenes by Akira Toriyama (which could be turned off at the viewer's discretion).
Square only brought out ports of the game, re-releases if you may, because they know there's no need to change a winning formula.
snippet.textOriginal:
Square's doing it right so far. 
Chrono Trigger on Playstation and Chrono Trigger DS weren't remakes at all, because the game itself was left virtually untouched. The only real noteworthy changes were that Frog's speech wasn't as "old English" on the DS, and they added awesome cutscenes by Akira Toriyama (which could be turned off at the viewer's discretion).
Square only brought out ports of the game, re-releases if you may, because they know there's no need to change a winning formula.

You do realise that there is a world of difference between a remake and a port? Obviously not, considering that you believe they're comparable.

I like to think of it as they want to leave testaments to better years, not that they don't believe other series' are worth it.

The huge overhanging problem is that we are reaching an incredibly delicate period of games. The market was saturated with low-quality games in 1983, which led to the video game crash. If companies aren't careful, that could easily happen again in the next few years.

snippet.textDisplay: @acidbath32 the problem with current Cel shaded graphics is that there's a "creamy" feeling or a pastel feeling to the graphics attached to it. Being able to truly render a game just like animes, I think the best solution would actually create an anime engine, that only use a string of photos, built only from raster images, not vector. This would also mean, no polygon at all, and the engine would feel like a giant stop motion, set at 24 frames per second to preserve the anime feeling.

snippet.textDisplay:
@icydesign I first played Chrono Trigger sometime in the 90's pretty soon after it came out. I thought it was alright, but I had only rented it, and didn't go on to buy it. I picked it up again several years later and discovered that it was a lot better than I originally thought. On the other hand I just picked up Chrono Cross a couple weeks ago.I have no idea why it took me so long to play the sequel to a game I loved so much.
Anyway, Yasunori Mitsuda is my favourite video game composer.
snippet.textOriginal:
@icydesign I first played Chrono Trigger sometime in the 90's pretty soon after it came out. I thought it was alright, but I had only rented it, and didn't go on to buy it. I picked it up again several years later and discovered that it was a lot better than I originally thought. On the other hand I just picked up Chrono Cross a couple weeks ago.I have no idea why it took me so long to play the sequel to a game I loved so much.
Anyway, Yasunori Mitsuda is my favourite video game composer.

snippet.textDisplay: @widdowson91 It's easy to forget, because the graphics of the day aren't impressive anymore, that developers DID invest a lot of time and effort into making cutting-edge graphics, even back then. It has always been one of the developer's top priorities, otherwise all games would look like something made for the Atari 2600. It's true that games don't seem to play as well as they used to, but it's for lack of talent, not for lack of trying. Developers priorities haven't changed a bit.
snippet.textOriginal: @widdowson91 It's easy to forget, because the graphics of the day aren't impressive anymore, that developers DID invest a lot of time and effort into making cutting-edge graphics, even back then. It has always been one of the developer's top priorities, otherwise all games would look like something made for the Atari 2600. It's true that games don't seem to play as well as they used to, but it's for lack of talent, not for lack of trying. Developers priorities haven't changed a bit.

snippet.textDisplay:
@Guergy Odds are it was all done on a synthesizer, but...

The dreamy scale in the background and opening melody is a vibrophone.
The drums are some sort of drum machine. I hear bongos and someone hitting Christmas-style jinglebells.
Then there are two synths doing the melody - one sounding like a chorus of violins, the other sounding like a distorted harp.
snippet.textOriginal:
@Guergy Odds are it was all done on a synthesizer, but...

The dreamy scale in the background and opening melody is a vibrophone.
The drums are some sort of drum machine. I hear bongos and someone hitting Christmas-style jinglebells.
Then there are two synths doing the melody - one sounding like a chorus of violins, the other sounding like a distorted harp.

snippet.textDisplay: @waddledoo812 I know this is a late response, but what I took from it (the game) was that, if anything, the Kingdom of Zeal really wasn't all that wise. At least not in the end, when Queen Zeal was being controlled by the Mammon Machine and Lavos.  She became too hungry for power, and *that's* when the Kingdom started to go downhill severely. I mean, there were warning signs before it, but I didn't feel like knowledge and power were the problems, but rather their hubris outstripped their wisdom.
snippet.textOriginal: @waddledoo812 I know this is a late response, but what I took from it (the game) was that, if anything, the Kingdom of Zeal really wasn't all that wise. At least not in the end, when Queen Zeal was being controlled by the Mammon Machine and Lavos.  She became too hungry for power, and *that's* when the Kingdom started to go downhill severely. I mean, there were warning signs before it, but I didn't feel like knowledge and power were the problems, but rather their hubris outstripped their wisdom.

Corruption was the catalyst.

snippet.textDisplay:
@BossBasher This shows just how much you're misinformed. Lost Odyssey isn't a Square Enix game. It was made by Mistwalker (check your game box if you don't believe me), the studio consisting of former members of Square. It's the current gen SquareSoft if you will. Lost Odyssey is a great game indeed. FFXIII was pretty mediocre and so was The Last Remnant and any other game by Square recently.

And while we're at it. Blue Dragon is also by Mistwalker.

snippet.textDisplay:
@BadTouch624

I couldn't disagree more! I thought the music perfectly set the mood of what was going on. At that point in the game you have no idea that there was far more advanced technology and magic 10.000 years in the past! The game throws you a curve ball. It was supposed to have a Wonderland feeling, because they seem so perfect on the outside, but you know that something happened to them because they are non-existent in the present! The story perfectly unfolds the corruption and downfall!
snippet.textOriginal:
@BadTouch624

snippet.textDisplay: Every time I listen to this song it brings me back to 1995! It reminds me of the floating island where the enlightened ones lived! And being interested in the Atlantis legends made this my favorite part of the game! I also like post-apocalyptic movies, so the ruined future was probably my next favorite part of the game. I just wish that you could have went to the year 1000 when Lavos attacked the earth! This game and Final Fantasy 6 had the best music from all the RPG's on the SNES!

Hoshigami and Luminious Arc are good examples.  I want to like them, but I just get bored for some reason.  The only DS exclusive RPGs I enjoyed were "Endless Frontier" and "The World Ends With You".  Same with Pokemon, if that counts.  Otherwise, I mostly get bored.  Oddly enough, I still play RPGs on SNES and Megadrive.

snippet.textDisplay: I think if enough of us who can do good writing, graphic design, coding, and music work together, we can bring back those days.  I've noticed a serious lack of good RPGs these days from all over.  Tactical RPGs, action RPGs, and spinoffs are about the only new games that comes close to the originals.  Otherwise, we see just rehash or an experimentation sold as revelutionary with no real story at all.  Even the new PSP titles I buy I eventually get bored of.

snippet.textDisplay:
When it came out, the strange hype that can surround a video games release turned out to be true!  Time-travel? Group attacks? Multiple endings?

It went from melodramatic to sweeping to heart-wrenching to world-ending, but is like no other rpg.  More dire and strategic than Secret of Mana, but more kinetic and gleaming than FF3. 

Truly a gem among Square's unbelievable successes.

snippet.textDisplay:
Games today go for better graphics instead of playability...

Soon enough, when this quest for better graphics ends, they will all turn to the playability factor since it's the only thing that really gets most gamers happy with no complaints. (I mean, look at crysis, great graphics, limited gameplay due to being story-based, and your char is almoust like a god, rarely dies...)

snippet.textDisplay: There are STILL good games being made.  The Paper Mario series are excellent spinoffs of the classic Super Mario RPG.  I also recommend Tales of Symphonia.  I do agree with your comment.  There are too many FPS games and fighting games.  Give it a little variety!  The SNES, N64, PS1, and PS2 all had good platformers, racing, and RPGs.  We need more platformers especially.  I still play my SNES and have accumulated 54 games over my 19 years.  SNES and I share the same age.

snippet.textDisplay:
The sitar and tabla make it sound very Indian, which combines with a lot of the Eastern-style spirituality of the Zeal people.

It's an ancient kingdom of flying islands and powerful magic, but this theme also sounds very powerful after the disaster that wipes out the kingdom and ends the ice age.

snippet.textDisplay: I still remember my first experience with this game.  Back in 5th grade in 1995, my friend who had a lot of RPGs introduced me to incredible games like this and Secret of Mana.  He brought the instruction book to class and drew a picture of Frog.  He couldn't play games often so I borrowed it from him and a few years later when he stopped playing games I got it for $20!  Still the best deal I've gotten on a video game.
snippet.textOriginal: I still remember my first experience with this game.  Back in 5th grade in 1995, my friend who had a lot of RPGs introduced me to incredible games like this and Secret of Mana.  He brought the instruction book to class and drew a picture of Frog.  He couldn't play games often so I borrowed it from him and a few years later when he stopped playing games I got it for $20!  Still the best deal I've gotten on a video game.

snippet.textDisplay: I agree.  It's a shame most people still don't realize that many video games are art.  I've been playing games like this for ages and my parents still don't realize that many old games had great music, art, story, and gameplay.  CT is a classic that will never be forgotten, and I love this song, still hear it in my head fairly often even thought it has been years since I've played the game and don't listen to game music on it's own much.
